content: The "Minority Inclusion in Clinical Trials Act of 2015" encourages the National Institute on Minority Health and Health Disparities to increase representation of underrepresented communities in clinical trials. Grants will be awarded to expand opportunities for scientists and researchers, as well as promote the inclusion of underrepresented minorities in the health professions. Support for institutions in underrepresented communities for workforce development. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will award grants to eligible entities that focus on health workforce development in underrepresented communities, including historically Black colleges, Hispanic-serving institutions, tribal colleges, and institutions with programs for minority health professionals. Entities eligible for grants include Asian-American, Native American, and Pacific Islander-serving institutions, institutions with programs to recruit and retain underrepresented minority health professionals, health professional associations, and institutions located in communities with predominantly underrepresented minority populations. These entities must have partnerships for increasing workforce diversity and at least 20 percent of enrolled participants must be underrepresented minorities. They must submit an application to the Secretary for consideration. Amounts received under a grant shall be used to expand existing workforce diversity programs, implement new programs, or evaluate existing or new programs, including mental health care professions. Programs should enhance diversity by considering minority status as part of an individualized consideration of qualifications. Eliminating disparities in maternity health outcomes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with various healthcare organizations, will conduct research and expand access to services to eliminate disparities in maternal health outcomes. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a demonstration project in up to 8 states to compare interventions aimed at reducing disparities in maternity services and outcomes. States will be selected based on applications specifying regions and populations to be served, ensuring representation of affected communities. The Secretary will conduct a demonstration project in up to 8 states to reduce disparities in maternity services. Criteria will ensure representation of affected communities and diverse intervention models with evidence-based effectiveness. The project will involve consultation with local provider organizations and run from January 1, 2015, to December 31, 2019. Grants may be provided for evaluation and monitoring. The Secretary will conduct a demonstration project in up to 8 states from January 1, 2015, to December 31, 2019, to reduce disparities in maternity services. Grants may be provided for evaluation and monitoring of the project, with states required to report data on outcomes, costs, and quality of care. A final report on the project results is due by December 31, 2020. The Secretary will submit a final report to Congress by December 31, 2020 on the results of the demonstration project, including items and services covered in bundled payments made by the State. SEC. 6. HEALTH DISPARITIES EDUCATION PROGRAM. The Secretary will establish a health and health care disparities education program in collaboration with various entities to inform professionals and the public about racial and ethnic disparities in health care. This program will disseminate scientific evidence and implement outreach campaigns to reduce these disparities. The program aims to disseminate scientific evidence on racial and ethnic disparities in health care, including factors like age, disability, socioeconomic status, and gender identity. It also aims to share new research findings with healthcare providers and patients to reduce disparities and address linguistic and cultural barriers in healthcare quality. The program focuses on addressing health care disparities by providing language access services, disseminating information on various factors affecting healthcare quality, educating healthcare providers, and assessing the impact of these initiatives. Authorization of appropriations is provided for fiscal years 2015 through 2020.
